metadata.case_name: Jugalkishore Saraf v. Raw Cotton Company Ltd.

facts.text: Mahomedali Habib and Sakerkhanoo Mahomedali Habib carried on business as merchants and pucca adatias in bullion and companyton at Bombay under the name Habib Sons.

In 1948, Habib Sons instituted Summary Suit No. 233 of 1948 in Bombay City Civil Court against Jugalkishore Saraf for recovery of Rs. 7,113-7-0 with interest at 6% per annum in respect of transactions in gold and silver.

On 7th February 1949, while the suit was pending, a document was executed whereby Habib Sons agreed to transfer to Raw Cotton Company Ltd. all book and other debts due in connection with their business in Bombay, full benefit of securities, and all other property to which they were entitled in connection with the said business.
Raw Cotton Company did not take steps under O. XXII r. 10 CPC to get substituted as plaintiffs in the suit, allowing it to continue in the name of original plaintiffs Habib Sons.
The two partners of Habib Sons migrated to Pakistan and their properties vested in the Custodian of Evacuee Property.

On 15th December 1949, decree passed in the summary suit for Rs. 8,018-7-0 for debt and interest, Rs. 410 costs, total Rs. 8,428-7-0, with further interest at 4% from date of decree, in favour of Habib Sons.
On 2nd August 1950, Additional Custodian confirmed the transfer of business of Habib Sons to Raw Cotton Company.
On 11th December 1950, Custodian informed Raw Cotton Company of the confirmation.

On or about 25th April 1951, Raw Cotton Company presented tabular statement as application for execution under O. XXI r. 11 CPC, praying for declaration as assignees of decree due to transfer dated 7th Feb 1949 confirmed by Custodian, and substitution.
No specification of modes of assistance under clause (j) of O. XXI r. 11 in the tabular statement.
On 10th May 1951, City Civil Court issued notice under O. XXI r. 16 to Habib Sons and Jugalkishore Saraf to show cause why decree should not be executed by transferees.
Jugalkishore Saraf filed affidavit on 15th June 1951 denying execution of document and that it transferred the decree.
Execution of document proved by attesting witness, accepted by executing court.
Executing court rejected contention on transfer, made notice absolute with costs, gave leave to Raw Cotton Company to execute.
Jugalkishore appealed to High Court (Appeal No. 67 of 1952), heard by Dixit J., execution not challenged, dismissed affirming lower court on authority of Bombay cases.
Letters Patent Appeal (Appeal No. 8 of 1953) dismissed by Chagla CJ and Shah J., following same authorities, granted certificate under Art. 133(1)(c).

legal_issues.text: Whether the respondent company can claim to be the transferees of the decree within the meaning of Order XXI, rule 16 of the Code of Civil Procedure.
Whether the document dated 7th February 1949 constituted an assignment of the future decree or operated in equity to transfer the decree upon its passing.
Whether the respondent company became transferees by operation of law under Order XXI rule 16.
Whether the respondent company can execute the decree under section 146 CPC as persons claiming under the decree-holder.

petitioner_arguments.text: Denied execution of the document dated 7th February 1949.
The document did not transfer the decree as it was executed before the decree was passed; no assignment of decree under O. XXI r. 16.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Order XXI rule 16 CPC; Transfer of Property Act s.8

petitioner_arguments.text: Equitable principles do not convert prior agreement into assignment in writing of decree; execution application defective under O. XXI r. 11.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Holroyd v. Marshall; precedents like Basroovittil Bhandari v. Ramchandra Kamthi

respondent_arguments.text: Document dated 7th February 1949 transferred all book debts and other property including the future decree in the pending suit; confirmed by Custodian.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Order XXI r. 16 CPC; equitable assignment principles from Holroyd v. Marshall, Collyer v. Isaacs

respondent_arguments.text: Transfer of debt carries right to decree; equitable principle fastens on decree upon passing, making them transferees by assignment or operation of law.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Purmananddas Jivandas v. Vallabdas Wallji; Chimanlal Hargovinddas v. Ghulamnabi; Transfer of Property Act s.8

court_reasoning.text: Literal construction of O. XXI r. 16 requires decree to exist before transfer by assignment in writing; document predates decree, no transfer of decree.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No apparent absurdity in literal construction.

court_reasoning.text: Document transfers existing book debts and properties to which vendors entitled at date; no mention of pending suit or future decree; s.8 TPA passes only then-existing interests.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No agreement to transfer future decree; equitable principle inapplicable without such agreement.

court_reasoning.text: Equitable principle treats as done what ought to be done but does not relate back to make prior agreement an assignment in writing; transfer by equity is by operation of law, not assignment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Equity operates dehors the prior agreement.

court_reasoning.text: Transfer by operation of law includes equitable transfers, court sales, insolvency, etc., not confined to death/succession; but no such transfer here as document excludes future decree.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Operation of law: passing of rights by force of law, statutory or otherwise.

court_reasoning.text: Respondents, as assignees of debt (subject-matter of suit), are real owners of decree passed thereon; claim under decree-holders as benamidars continued suit; entitled under s.146 CPC.
court_reasoning.key_observation: O. XXI r.16 not bar; s.146 applies to persons claiming under decree-holder.

court_reasoning.text: Execution application defective but no objection taken; later compliant application filed.

holdings.text: Document dated 7th Feb 1949 does not transfer or agree to transfer the future decree; no assignment in writing or by operation of law under O. XXI r.16.
Equitable principles do not convert prior transfer of debt into assignment of subsequent decree under O. XXI r.16.
Transferees of debt before decree, who allow suit to continue in transferors' name, are persons claiming under decree-holders and can execute under s.146 CPC.

precedents_cited.relevance: Held assignee entitled by operation of law/equity; but court views as operation of law, not assignment in writing.
Transfer of rights under award included decree; intention clear, unlike here.
Equitable principle: contract to transfer future property fastens equity on acquisition.
Contract to assign future property becomes complete assignment in equity.

precedents_cited.case_name: Performing Right Society v. London Theatre of Varieties
precedents_cited.relevance: Equitable interest does not make prior instrument statutory assignment; no relation back.
No equitable assignment of future decree under O.XXI r.16.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mathurapore Zamindary Co. Ltd. v. Bhasaram Mandal
precedents_cited.relevance: Transferee of property before decree not transferee of decree under O.XXI r.16.
Operation of law not limited to death/succession.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs execution by transferees of decree; s.146 allows persons claiming under decree-holder to execute.

statutes_cited.name: Transfer of Property Act, 1882
statutes_cited.relevance: Transfer passes interests transferor capable of passing at time; no future property.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; respondent company entitled to execute decree under s.146 CPC as assignees of debt claiming under decree-holders Habib Sons, despite not being transferees under O.XXI r.16.

key_quotes.text: "The cardinal rule of construction of statutes is to read the statute literally, that is by giving to the words used by the legislature their ordinary, natural and grammatical meaning."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Basis for interpreting O.XXI r.16 literally.

key_quotes.text: "Equity fastens upon the after-acquired property and treats the beneficial interest therein as transferred to the intending transferee."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains equitable principle but denies relation back to assignment.

key_quotes.text: "The respondent company were after the transfer, the owners of the debt which was the subject matter of the suit and the legal incidents thereof and consequently were the real owners of the decree."
key_quotes.speaker: court
